Alaska
Verso: Alaska

Jan 1, 1975; Dear Lowell: Our happiest wishes to you for 1975! It has to be a great year for us all, and especially you. Certainly it will be for Sonny and Tay and family. They'll have the ski place in Juneau this summer - so it's time for your return to the high camps of JIPP. Let's count on it - say in late July - Affectionately, Mel, Joan, Ross and Lance; View East across the Juneau ice field; M. M. Miller

Verso: Jan 1, 1975; Dear Lowell: Our happiest wishes to you for 1975! It has to be a great year for us all, and especially you. Certainly it will be for Sonny and Tay and family. They'll have the ski place in Juneau this summer - so it's time for your return to the high camps of JIPP. Let's count on it - say in late July - Affectionately, Mel, Joan, Ross and Lance; View East across the Juneau ice field; M. M. Miller

One of the farthest north clubhouses in the world, the home of the Dawson American Athletic Association. It contains club rooms, ball room, curling rinks, moving picture show, and hockey rink and has 10,000 feet of floor space. C. A. Creamer, former advance man for Barnum & Bailey has been at the head of it for 17 years

Verso: One of the farthest north clubhouses in the world, the home of the Dawson American Athletic Association. It contains club rooms, ball room, curling rinks, moving picture show, and hockey rink and has 10,000 feet of floor space. C. A. Alaska: Leather trunk series

Note: The enclosed two pictures were taken on the way to Atlin. This reflection is of a mountain on the shore of Taku Inlet one mile from Indian Point and about ten miles from Lake Atlin. Several people I have shown the reflection picture to have declared it a fake. They couldn't believe it possible to get such a perfect reflection, but they were wrong. I have another that is even more beautiful which I will send you as soon as I get a print of it. On this picture I have been unable to decide which part is the reflection and which isn't but I believe the lighter half is not the mirrored part because the detail of the trees seems a trifle plainer [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]
[Alaskan landscape]
[Boat in Alaska]

Note: The launch picture was taken on the lake [Lake Atlin] itself. The launch was made by hand, by an old Swiss jeweler, who worked on it in his spare hours for several years [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan] [from larger note]

Leather trunk series - Fort Seward
Note: Letter describing pictures

The two enclosed pictures are of snapshots I took on my first visit to Haines and Fort Seward, June 26th [1916]. The one of the soldiers drilling was taken on the parade ground at the Fort with Portage Bay in the back ground. Two companies are stationed at this post with a total enrollment of about 200 men. The building to the right is the hospital, to the left the barracks of Company C. in between are some of the residences of married non-commissioned officers and extending out in the bay is the Fort dock with the "Peterson" tied along side [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]
Verso: description from letter describing series
[Fort Seward]
Fort Seward
Verso: Fort Seward
[Fort Seward]
[Fort Seward]
Major McAndrew's wife on the S.S. Peterson
Verso: Major McAndrew's wife on the S.S. Peterson

The morning of the Fourth [July 1916] I went down with a crowd from Skagway to get a few feet of film on the baseball game between the soldiers and the Indians, the canoe race, the tug of war, the greased pole contest, the obstacle race, the sprints between the natives and the track men from the Fort and the gas-boat race [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]
Verso: description from letter describing series

The morning of the Fourth [July 1916] I went down with a crowd from Skagway to get a few feet of film on the baseball game between the soldiers and the Indians, the canoe race, the tug of war, the greased pole contest, the obstacle race, the sprints between the natives and the track men from the Fort and the gas-boat race [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]
Verso: description from letter describing series

The morning of the Fourth [July 1916] I went down with a crowd from Skagway to get a few feet of film on the baseball game between the soldiers and the Indians, the canoe race, the tug of war, the greased pole contest, the obstacle race, the sprints between natives and the track men from the Fort and the gas-boat race [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]
Verso: description from letter describing series

This other snapshot is of an old prospector on his way back to the creeks after laying in a few week's supplies. Although a bachelor, who has lived for the past ten years out in the wilderness all alone, barely panning enough colors to pay for his grub, he seems to get a lot of joy out of life and rides along the mountain roads strumming on his guitar and singing as though he had the whole world by the horns [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]
Verso: description from letter describing series
[no description]
Alaska: Leather trunk series - friends of Lowell Thomas

Grave of an Indian chief, at Wrangell. The two totems represent the "killer" whale, which was the animal of chieftan's family. One of the girls is a stenog[grapher] from Portland and the one in the white hat and dress lives up near the Arctic Circle at Ruby. Their companions are the "Edelweiss twins," Edward and George Seippel [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]

Verso: Grave of an Indian chief, at Wrangell. The two totems represent the "killer" whale, which was the animal of chieftan's family. One of the girls is a stenog[grapher] from Portland and the one in the white hat and dress lives up near the Arctic Circle at Ruby. Their companions are the "Edelweiss twins," Edward and George Seippel [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]

Prof. Gorgeson, of Sitka, Alaskan agricultural expert and his wife who were on the "Jefferson" coming up. They want us to visit them next summer and sample the largest strawberries in the world which are grown by the U.S. experiment station there [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]

Verso: Prof. Gorgeson, of Sitka, Alaskan agricultural expert and his wife who were on the "Jefferson" coming up. They want us to visit them next summer and sample the largest strawberries in the world which are grown by the U.S. experiment station there [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]

One of the Edelweiss twins took this picture the day we hiked up the mountain at George's Inlet cannery. It was about 30 minutes later that I fell off the log I wrote you about sometime ago. These girls are stenographers for a Portland canning company. They claimed the Edelweiss brothers and me as their private property before the boat left Seattle [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]

Verso: One of the Edelweiss twins took this picture the day we hiked up the mountain at George's Inlet cannery. It was about 30 minutes later that I fell off the log I wrote you about sometime ago. These girls are stenographers for a Portland canning company. They claimed the Edelweiss brothers and me as their private property before the boat left Seattle [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]

Alaska: Leather trunk series - mountaineers
Note: [letter from Lowell Thomas to Frances Ryan], [PDF]
(The President of the Alaskan Mountaineers, hunting mountain goats among the glaciers and the crags of Chilkat mountains)
The President of the Alaskan Mountaineers, hunting mountain goats among the glaciers and the crags of Chilkat mountains. Whoope-e-e-e!!
Verso: The President of the Alaskan Mountaineers, hunting mountain goats among the glaciers and the crags of Chilkat mountains. Whoope-e-e-e!!

The enclosed snapshot taken of four "Alaskan Mountaineers" ascending a snowbank on the way to the summit of the "A.B.," back of Skagway, is another in which the camera was tipped so that the perpendicularity of the grade was lost. It looks as though we were on an almost level stretch of snow but it really was so steep we had to sink our toes in several inches at each step to keep from taking a mile-a-minute ride to the bottom of the mountain [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan] [descrption an except from letter]

Gastineau channel near Thane, Alaska. S.S. Prince Rupert with Juneau, Alaska, to the left 1 mile away. {The other is a snapshot of Taku glacier with the S.S. Prince Rupert of the Grand Trunk Pacific line directly in front of it. This picture was taken at 4 o'clock in the morning while it was still twilight [photograph accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan]}
Verso1: Gastineau channel near Thane, Alaska. S.S. Prince Rupert with Juneau, Alaska, to the left 1 mile away.

Notice the look on the face of the man below. Mr. Cole's hobnailed boots were making raw beefsteak out of my shoulder and we were on a ledge only a few inches wide with a 300 foot drop directly underneath. This picture, like all but one of the others we took that day, fails to show how steep the mt. was

Verso: Notice the look on the face of the man below. Mr. Cole's hobnailed boots were making raw beefsteak out of my shoulder and we were on a ledge only a few inches wide with a 300 foot drop directly underneath. This picture, like all but one of the others we took that day, fails to show how steep the mt. was

By the time we got to the summit of "A.B.," mountain all the fellows were perspiring like a man fireing [sic] an engine on the "Cape to Cairo" railroad crossing the equator. This is a picture of one of the gang posing as Lady Godiva. The water in the distance is Lynn Canal. Unfortunately it was a hazy day or the picture would show the canal for 50 miles

Verso: By the time we got to the summit of "A.B.," mountain all the fellows were perspiring like a man fireing [sic] an engine on the "Cape to Cairo" railroad crossing the equator. This is a picture of one of the gang posing as Lady Godiva. The water in the distance is Lynn Canal. Unfortunately it was a hazy day or the picture would show the canal for 50 miles

Alaska: Leather trunk series - Peel River and Porcupine Indians

Former chief of the Porcupines making snowshoes. This Indian resigned as chief of the tribe in 1888, ten years before gold was discovered in the Klondike, on account of old age. This picture was taken July 2nd, 1916

Alaska: Leather trunk series - Lowell Thomas automobile trip
Autoing [sic] in the wilds of Alaska
Verso: Autoing [sic] in the wilds of Alaska
Bishop P.T. Rowe and Mr. Thomas on a 400 mile auto trip through the heart of the Alaskan wilderness. Alaska needs millions of dollars for roads to help develop its resources
Verso: Bishop P.T. Rowe and Mr. Thomas on a 400 mile auto trip through the heart of the Alaskan wilderness. Alaska needs millions of dollars for roads to help develop its resources
Motoring through the heart of Alaska with the temperature 90 above zero
Verso: Motoring through the heart of Alaska with the temperature 90 above zero
The government has built an automobile road 470 miles long through the heart of Alaska from Valdez to Fairbanks. A machine has to be overhauled and sometimes completely replaced after about 2 trips

V-1; William Vance dressed in Eskimo costume. Photo taken at Eskimo Point

V-8; Vance with a beard
Verso: V-8; Vance with a beard
V-9; Eskimo tent at Baker Lake. There is an assortment of caribou hides unsold, with guns

V-10; Taken at Churchill on the 6th of May, 1929. Left to right: Vance, Hugh Conn, General Inspector of Hudsons Bay Company, Tom Creighton one of the discoverers of the Flinn Flawn [Flin Flon] Mine, Burke[?] Schiller, and Joe Hunter

V-11; An airplane on the ice at Churchill
Verso: V-11; An airplane on the ice at Churchill
V-12; An airplane on the ice at Churchill
Verso: V-12; An airplane on the ice at Churchill
Verso: V-13; Fish hanging on a clothes line. Fish dried in this manner would keep indefinitely. Large quantities are dried every summer both for dog food and human consumption during the winter
V-13; Fish hanging on a clothes line. Fish dried in this manner would keep indefinitely. Large quantities are dried every summer both for dog food and human consumption during the winter
To my friends J.D. Vance + Brian Blasdale from A. Dugalle, Canadian National Photographer, 30-3-30

Verso: V-14; Photo taken at the end of our journey at mile 327 Hudsons Bay Railway. This was taken the day after we reached this place. We had both shaved and washed several times, although there are indications that it does not look like it
V-15; Typical Eskimo woman's outfit
Verso: V-15; Typical Eskimo woman's outfit
V-16; Rather a fine old man, a native. Note that his beard is iced up
Verso: V-16; Rather a fine old man, a native. Note that his beard is iced up
V-17; A native with his beard frozen
Verso: V-17; A native with his beard frozen
V-18; A young woman by the name of Attah. Very typical of Eskimo women in appearance. She is of the tribe Ivilingmuit
Verso: V-18; A young woman by the name of Attah. Very typical of Eskimo women in appearance. She is of the tribe Ivilingmuit
V-19; An Eskimo woman, Shum-mik. Rather a fine old lady who lives at Baker Lake. She does excellent needle work and has seen many winters. She is of the tribe Hanermuit
Verso: V-19; An Eskimo woman, Shum-mik. Rather a fine old lady who lives at Baker Lake. She does excellent needle work and has seen many winters. She is of the tribe Hanermuit

V-20; Kay ak took is of the tribe Aksiligsilingmuit, a member of one of the more primitive tribes. Many members of this tribe had never seen a trading post, usually sending one of two men into Baker Lake once a year to trade for the entire tribe

Verso: V-20; Kay ak took is of the tribe Aksiligsilingmuit, a member of one of the more primitive tribes. Many members of this tribe had never seen a trading post, usually sending one of two men into Baker Lake once a year to trade for the entire tribe

V-21; A typical Eskimo kommitik[?] with the entire household goods packed up ready to move two or three hundred miles to a new hunting ground. It is not necessary to carry the house as it will be made from snow blocks wherever they decide to camp. Note the runners which are made of mud. The native term for mud is Noona which means land

Verso: V-21; A typical Eskimo kommitik[?] with the entire household goods packed up ready to move two or three hundred miles to a new hunting ground. It is not necessary to carry the house as it will be made from snow blocks wherever they decide to camp. Note the runners which are made of mud. The native term for mud is Noona which means land
V-22; Niak-ko, one of the Aksiligsilingmuit. Niak-ko has a more pointed mustache and beard than is usual among the Eskimos who are usual clean of hair, there not being much hair on their faces
Verso: V-22; Niak-ko, one of the Aksiligsilingmuit. Niak-ko has a more pointed mustache and beard than is usual among the Eskimos who are usual clean of hair, there not being much hair on their faces
V-23; A typical scene when building an igloo. The blocks are cut out from in inside
Verso: V-23; A typical scene when building an igloo. The blocks are cut out from in inside
V-24; A white whale which is hunted in the same style as walrus
Verso: V-24; A white whale which is hunted in the same style as walrus
V-25; A young Eskimo boy
Verso: V-25; A young Eskimo boy

V-26; The same machine which is now at Baker Lake. This photo was taken near The Pas, Manitoba, on May 6, 1929, just after flying out from Churchill. The machine was run up on the shore ready to change to pontoons when the ice melted

Verso: V-26; The same machine which is now at Baker Lake. This photo was taken near The Pas, Manitoba, on May 6, 1929, just after flying out from Churchill. The machine was run up on the shore ready to change to pontoons when the ice melted
V-27; Sirpapik who has been rather a belle in her own days
Verso: V-27; Sirpapik who has been rather a belle in her own days
28; A typical trading post, banked up for warmth. This snow is banked as protection against the wind
Verso: 28; A typical trading post, banked up for warmth. This snow is banked as protection against the wind
V-29; Bob Stewart, one of the most picturesque of the northern traders, with part of the season's catch
Verso: V-29; Bob Stewart, one of the most picturesque of the northern traders, with part of the season's catch
V-30; Typical Eskimo dogs. Photo taken at Eskimo Point
Verso: V-30; Typical Eskimo dogs. Photo taken at Eskimo Point

V-31; A typical Eskimo igloo showing the man and wife standing in the entrance. A kommitik is on top of the igloo. These igloos, although it is difficult to build them, are strong enough to stand heavy weights. A few minutes after they are erected a man may walk on them

Verso: V-31; A typical Eskimo igloo showing the man and wife standing in the entrance. A kommitik is on top of the igloo. These igloos, although it is difficult to build them, are strong enough to stand heavy weights. A few minutes after they are erected a man may walk on them
V-32; An igloo in the course of construction. The builder is inside cutting out snow blocks
Verso: V-32; An igloo in the course of construction. The builder is inside cutting out snow blocks
V-33; Scene building an igloo. The blocks are fitted one into another. The igloo is built in circular fashion, gradually narrowing into the center, the last block being dropped in like a wedge
Verso: V-33; Scene building an igloo. The blocks are fitted one into another. The igloo is built in circular fashion, gradually narrowing into the center, the last block being dropped in like a wedge
V-34; Another scene building an igloo. Instrument used is a long knife
Verso: V-34; Another scene building an igloo. Instrument used is a long knife

Verso: V-36 A typical husky dog

Verso: V-37; Another view of a kommitik

Verso: V-38; Nalik ti, which in English means "the one who listens." An excellent type of husky dog, grey in color

V-45; Aerial view of Sioux Lookout [Ontario]. The busiest airplane base Abram Lake in foreground Pelican Lake in background.

V-46; Waterfall in Northern Manitoba in country many miles from rail
Verso: V-46; Waterfall in Northern Manitoba in country many miles from rail

V-47; My plane at Eskimo Point, April 1929. After a ten day's drift. Before the storm, the surface was level. The background is indistinct owing to the glare on the snow, and the low lying nature of the topography. The land being almost on the same level as the sea at this point

Verso: V-47; My plane at Eskimo Point, April 1929. After a ten day's drift. Before the storm, the surface was level. The background is indistinct owing to the glare on the snow, and the low lying nature of the topography. The land being almost on the same level as the sea at this point
V-48; Dooley-a Padlermuit of Eskimo Point
Verso: V-48; Dooley-a Padlermuit of Eskimo Point
V-49; Akpa, a Padlermuit. One of our guides. This man was most polite. His manners very courteous, somewhat like a Frenchman
Verso: V-49; Akpa, a Padlermuit. One of our guides. This man was most polite. His manners very courteous, somewhat like a Frenchman
V-50; Two little girls at Eskimo Point. Note the igloo in rear. One little girl is wearing an artigi too large for her-her mother's
Verso: V-50; Two little girls at Eskimo Point. Note the igloo in rear. One little girl is wearing an artigi too large for her-her mother's
